awd_abstract_narration:
Communication among humans is known to be complex, which is perhaps why some technologies of communication go unrecognized by their users. For example, written communications, whether public signage, billboards, books, instruction manuals, or even consumer electronics interfaces, depend on the purposeful deployment of typefaces and fonts. The typeface or font chosen in each case carries its own meaning, which influences the message received and resonates with readers through these shared cultural forms, even if readers are unaware. Surprisingly, considering typeface's ubiquity and importance, this area of social life has been little studied. Social scientists have examined typeface primarily in narrow, cognitive terms, such as by studying relative readability. But much wider research is needed to understand how the many different typefaces that populate societies are created, selected, and used, and how they ultimately build and influence communication.

Dr. Keith M. Murphy, an anthropologist at the University of California at Irvine, will undertake an ethnographic and discourse analytic investigation of how varieties of printed language mediate communication. The research will focus on typographic design and pedagogy; decision making around the use of typeface for public communication; and the curation and cultivation of typographic knowledge. Data will be collected through semi-structured interviews, participant observation, video-recorded activity analyses, and archival research, in studios, classrooms, and archives, primarily in San Francisco, Los Angeles, and New York City. Data analysis will include an innovative use of techniques from archaeology to examine relations between typographic specimen categories and contexts of use. Findings from this research will elucidate how typeface influences the messages people send and receive. Theoretically, the research expands upon social scientific understanding of the materiality of human communication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The ethnographic research conducted for this project has yielded the first comprehensive analysis of contemporary writing and writing systems since the 1950s. The project began by focusing on how typography — the stylization of letters and characters — is rendered socially meaningful by specialized practitioners. Subsequent data analysis revealed that those typographic details are only one part of a much more complex technological system underlying the functionality and social significance of writing itself. Because many of the domains I’ve analyzed have never been examined alongside one another, and some of what I've explored hasn’t even been studied before, the project ended up striking on something unanticipated: a new way to think about the position of writing in society. Some notable findings that emerged from the data:

1) Digital writing — mostly in what we think of as “fonts” — emerged from a carefully (though not always intentionally) guided convergence of law and mathematics

2) Old and outdated forms of printing are preserved in a state of “unobselescence” — not quite disappearing — by merging their capabilities with modern digital design technologies

3) Type design has historically looked to new technologies to enhance, change, or update writing for more modern usage, yet the forms of the past have always dominated, and continue to remain dominant. Times New Roman, for example, is based on a nearly 100-year-old typeface, which itself was inspired by the lettering of ancient Rome. However, recent changes to the social composition of the type design profession — that is, the people, not the technology — has made significant headway in innovating what writing can do and be used for

4) Most of the world’s writing systems work on digital devices because they’re encoded in the Unicode Standard. The people who manage the Unicode Standard have developed an important (though largely unrecognized) subroutine within the management process that requires “human data” (like history and culture) to be transformed into “technical data,” which makes it compatible for inclusion in a system explicitly characterized as “non-political”

5) Almost all of the research on type and legibility and/or readability is wrong or severely overstated. The effects found in such research are usually quite small and highly qualified. This is partly due to a logical flaw that’s been inherited from the earliest days of legibility research (roughly the 1880s)…

6) …nonetheless, the desire to “activate” the power of type and fonts to produce a range of potential cognitive and social outcomes is strong among typographic professionals

7) Type and graphic design archives provide a space for preserving specimens of typographical importance, but also for people to experience those specimens in an embodied way, distinct from simply looking at them online. This is seen as an increasingly important mission, as more and more people (especially new designers) experience fewer and fewer physical graphic objects. There is a subdued but resonant anxiety among both designers and design archivists that something important about human communication (and culture in general) will be lost as type and graphic design move away from tangible, storable things to exist solely in digital domains.
